IRM 2.7.6, dated January 1, 2010, is superseded.
These guidelines are for the Information Technology Services (ITS) staff in the Enterprise Computing have system scheduling roles and responsibilities.
Table of Contents
Scheduling
) Overview: To arrange and organize in a programmatic way the execution of daily and weekly processing for Enterprise Computing Center for both and Memphis (ECC-MEM) and Martinsburg (ECC-MTB). (
) Purpose: This IRM reinstates Internal Revenue Manual (IRM)
, tion Technology Services (ITS) Operations, Systems Scheduling for service center tax processing. (

) Audience: IT Application Development (AD) – Developers who coordinate Operations Services Branch (OSB) to schedule jobs on the IBM Mainframe and UNISYS, IT OSB IBM Mainframe and UNISYS Schedulers and IT Mainframe Operations Branch (MOB) Computer Systems Analyst (CSA). (
) Policy Owner: Chief Information Officer. (
) Program Owner: Enterprise Computing Center, Operations Scheduling (OSB). (
) Primary Stakeholders: IT Applications Development (AD) and Operations Scheduling Branch (OSB). (
) Program Goals: Provides detailed Scheduling processes and procedures. (

) This section presents the general concepts to be followed in the creation of schedules for all processing; the preparation of run set-ups; the review of these prior to, and following, the completion of the work on the system. (
) This section on ITS Scheduling is applicable to most offices within the IRS schedule computer equipment for processing or testing of live data and provides basic Scheduling functions. (

) The goals of an effective scheduling system include: • Timely completion of all processing; • maximum utilization of all available resources; • proper identiﬁcation of all the processing that should be completed the allocated time frames; • speciﬁc avoidance of processing that conﬂict within the computer systems; • careful consideration of all processing interdependencies between computer systems and sites; • current status of all ongoing processing and projected completion for management information; • protecting the information processd by ensuring proper security and privacy. (

) It is the responsibility of the senior ITS Operations manager to ensure that data is processed timely, completely, and within the guidelines set forth in document and other appropriate IRS procedures and directives. (

) This section provides the following abbreviations/acronyms. • AAF:Automatic Attribute Feature. • ATR:Automated Tracking Report. • BLISS:Basic Library Inquiry Sub-System. • BRM:Business Reports Monthly. (

) Daily schedules are built through the Opcon at

hours, Monday Thursday, by the program PRODBLD-M-T. This builds the daily schedule Schedules the following day. On Friday, the program PRODBLD-FRI runs to build schedules for Saturday, Sunday and Monday. (

This segment is to provide standard operating procedures for the preparation and distribution of the Systems Notiﬁcation.
) The appropriate Section or Branch prepares a Systems Notiﬁcation on an as needed basis to inform and instruct the personnel of scheduling changes in computer processing operations. (

) The following guidelines are provided for preparing a Systems Notiﬁcation: • Obtain a number from the Change Management Team. • Prepare a free form word processing document detailing scheduling changes in computer processing operations (e.g., holidays, power outages, extended IRSC cutoff, expedited processing, changes in of computer operations at ECC, changes in distribution of output ﬁles unit destinations, extended or date changes for real-time, rerouting of command codes, etc.). (

) Use the website to prepare a Systems Notiﬁcation at: http:// mountaineer.mcc.irs.gov.. When completed send an email to address,*ccmccb@irs.gov.. • After approval of the Systems Notiﬁcation, it will be disseminated via E-mail to managers of all responsible and impacted areas. NUMBER: WMB-

NUMBER: WMB-99-039 DATE: 03/29/1999
Systems Notiﬁcation
SUBJECT: Balancing Workload

Due to the current system problems, we are recommending close monitoring and scheduling actions to ensure that workload is balanced between the MBH1 and the MEH2 Systems. Please ensure that CFOL remains on the MBH1. If SOC4’s are encountered, please restart at checkpoint or BOJ and validate the SOC4 prior to opening problem resolution ticket.
Any questions or concerns can be directed to Janet Doe, Master File Scheduling Section, telephone number XXX-XXX-XXXX.

There will be numerous instances when the IRSC customer will request ad hoc job or special instructions be included in the Enterprise Computing Center production schedule. This segment does not address Enterprise Computing Center where the customer has demand terminal access or when the IRSC customer has the need to provide the IRSC with the authority to job/run after a system halt i.e., TEP, RPS, etc. See the following this information. Special instructions and any processing information provided to the Computing Center will be automated to the extent that they will be to the ECC via a customer service request via KISAM. Until that time or KISAM is not available, these interim or backup procedures will remain in effect.

Upon completion of each SCIPAS, a SCIPAS Processing Summary Report is generated. The reports are automatically sent to Control-D and can be accessed on-line under the following report names / job names:

MASTER FILE REPORT NAME JOB NAME PROJECT Routers & SCIPASJ RRPA90PA RRPA90PC / RRPA90PD IMF SCIPASI / RRPA90PI BMF SCIPASB RRPA90PB EPMF SCIPASE RRPA90PE TRDB SCIPAST RRPA90PF / RRPA90PH TETR SCIPASD RRPA90PG

SCIPAS reports are divided into four sections: The “NDM Receipts” section is a cumulative list of all ﬁles that were scheduled by SCIPAS and processed into the current cycle. This includes record counts for the ﬁles and also identiﬁes the job that processed the ﬁles. The “Application Program” section lists the jobs that processed the various input ﬁles that are scheduled by SCIPAS. This section includes projected and actual counts for the jobs, a list of inputs for each job, record counts/money amounts from LARS if available, and subsequent jobs that processed the output ﬁles from these jobs. The “DUP Check” section lists the SCIPAS duplicate ﬁle check jobs processed the various service center ﬁles. The “Cards And Messages” section contains several sub

sections. The “Holds And Releases” section lists the SCIPAS ‘action cards’ that were built by the Master File Schedulers. Action cards aid in the control and resolution of potential problems that were identiﬁed (ﬂagged) on SCIPAS reports. The “Missing File” section lists control ﬁles that were received without a corresponding data ﬁle. Files listed in this section must be researched the Master File Schedulers to ensure that the missing ﬁles are

The SCIPAS reports identify (ﬂag) many potential error conditions. When certain conditions are met, SCIPAS will hold the ﬁle or job and mark it with a series of asterisks (
). Any ﬁle or job marked with asterisks must be in
vestigated and corrective action must be taken in order for the ﬁle or job to be processed. Listed below are examples of the error conditions that SCIPAS identiﬁes.

****FAILED DUP CHECK message: generated when the duplicate data job detects a possible duplicate condition.
****DUPLICATE DOCUMENT NUMBER message: generated when the duplicate data job ﬁnds a duplicate document number.
****DUPLICATE SCHEDULE NUMBER message: generated when the duplicate data job ﬁnds a duplicate schedule number on the RDO ﬁles.
****CONTROL FILE IS CORRUPT message: generated when the duplicate data job cannot read the control ﬁle.
****WORK GROUP IS OUT OF SEQUENCE message: generated the work groups aren’t received in order.
****DATA FILE CNT = ??? CONTROL CNT = ??? message: generated when the data ﬁle and the control ﬁle counts do not match. (Note: ??? represents numeric counts)
****THE FORMAT OF THE WORK GROUP IS INCORRECT message: generated when the work group format is incorrect.
****PROBLEM FOUND, CHECK LARS LOG message: generated an out-of-balance occurs in the B
job.
****THERE IS NO ORIGINAL TO REPLACE message: generated replacement ﬁle is received before the original ﬁle.

Action Card Purpose Description ACC Accept High Return Code or Abend Accepts an abend or a condition code that Condition has been ﬂagged as unacceptable. The job is marked as successfully completed and its associated output will then be scheduled into subsequent processing. COM Add Processing Comment Records information about a particular situation for a ﬁle or job. The comments will appear on the SCIPAS reports. DRP Drop a File or Job Drops speciﬁc ﬁles or jobs that have been processed and automatically reruns sub- sequent (“downstream”) jobs. HLD Hold a File or Job Places a hold on a ﬁle or job so that it will not be scheduled until it is released by the Master File Schedulers. It should be noted that ﬁles can be held before they are received or created. ISO Isolate a File Isolates a Service Center ﬁle so that it is processed as a single input. RDP Release Duplicate File Releases ﬁles which have been identiﬁed as potential duplicates and allows them to process. REL Release Hold Releases ﬁles/ jobs previously held by MFS or jobs that have been ﬂagged by SCIPAS due to various error conditions. RER Rerun a Job Schedules the rerun of a job. All subse- quent (“downstream”) jobs will automatically rerun. RSF Reschedule a File Reschedules an input ﬁle that was not successfully processed or was dropped.

Action Card Purpose Description RSI Reschedule Inputs to a Job Reschedules all inputs from a prior cycle job into a new cycle. If the original job was successfully processed, the RSI card cannot be used. RSR Reschedule a Run Reschedules a job that is not pass oriented and adds additional inputs for processing. All subsequent (“downstream”) jobs will automatically rerun. PKH Packet Hold Prevents a job from being scheduled. Packet Holds are typically used when waiting for the transmission of new JCL. PKR Packet Release Releases a job and perIT scheduling.

) In most cases, when a replacement is needed for a ﬁle that has been fully transmitted, the Service Center Campus MUST transmit the replacement with the letter “R” in the workgroup. The letter “R” should NOT be used in the DSN of control ﬁles. If a control ﬁle replacement is needed, the original control ﬁle will need to be uncatalogededued and the replacement should be sent with the same DSN as the original control ﬁle. Additionally, the letter “R” should NOT be used in the DSN of replacement ﬁles for TRDB or data from BFS (TRACS and RDO ﬁles). TRDB jobs require special recovery processing before a ﬁle can be rerun. If a replacement is needed, the original ﬁle will to be uncatalogedued and the replacement ﬁle should be sent with the same DSN as the original ﬁle. a. If an “R” replacement ﬁle is received and the original ﬁle is still awaiting scheduling on the SCIPAS Scheduling ﬁle (Ru

ase), SCIPAS will the original ﬁle and automatically schedule the replacement ﬁle. b. If MFS is aware that an “R” replacement is forthcoming and the original ﬁle has not yet been processed, a hold (HLD) card should be built to place a hold on the original ﬁle. When the “R” replacement ﬁle is received, SCIPAS will automatically schedule the replacement ﬁle. c. If the original ﬁle has already been processed and an “R” replacement is received, the original ﬁle will be dropped and the original pass of the job will be processed without that ﬁle. The replacement ﬁle will be scheduled as the only input into a new pass of the job. The receipt of the “R” replacement ﬁle automatically initiates this process. d. When the message “***** Control File Is Corrupt” is displayed in the SCIPAS report, the control ﬁle must be replaced according to established procedures. After the newly transmitted control ﬁle is received, the pass of the Dup Check job associated with the original corrupted ﬁle must be rerun. Note: If the Dup Check job is current cycle, a RER (rerun) card can be built. If the Dup Check job is from a prior cycle, MFS must manually rerun the Dup Check job WITHOUT the SCIPAS Kick steps.

) Prior to the IRSC Mainframe Consolidation Project, the IRSCs adjusted ﬁle tentions at the local level. The motivation to change these retentions varied Changes to from site to site but most often involved extending retentions to avoid recreates. Oversight and security entities are another source of these ﬁle tensions. These offices would request that local management extend on selected ﬁles for use at a later date. These ﬁles were generally used for research, investigations, etc. (

) The inconsistency of retentions on identical ﬁles processed at each IRSC had a negative impact on the system scheduling and the disaster recovery segments of the consolidation effort. File extensions have expanded the equipment resources needed for processing at the computing centers, and required Programmers/CSAs to change ECL and reimpose local extensions with the receipt of each new updated program transmittal. ) IRSC balancing is a process that veriﬁes records transferred, merged, processed, added or deleted before, during, or after processing. For the Balancing purpose of this segment, balancing can be broken down into two Automated run-to-run balancing and manual balancing. (

) Because of delays in automating some run-to-run balancing tasks, and in the development of an automated system, a manual process will serve in the interim. Unfortunately, the manual process will be labor and paper intensive. Later in this document, we describe these new procedures. (
) There are multiple aspects of balancing: run-to-run balancing, manual balancing, balancing external ﬁles, balancing with Production Control (PCI). (
) This is an automated balancing process that is internal to the application or job-run stream. This function veriﬁes that the appropriate record counts are (R

R) carried throughout the application, or the record counts are carried forward from one application to another as in a multiple application job-run stream. a rule, that process is transparent to the operator unless an out-of-balance condition is identiﬁed. (
) If an out-of-balance condition occurs, the operator will contact the clerk or MTB Schedulers. Many times, depending on the application, the of-balance condition may be corrected at that point. (
) If an out-of-balance condition cannot be corrected locally, notify the KISAM ordinator and prepare a trouble ticket in the usual manner. (

) The computing centers require two supporting systems software packages assist in the balancing process. These systems speed the balancing and are not considered automation tools. They are: • Electronic Online Notiﬁcation System (EONS), and • Computer Balancing Application (CBA), Version

) EONS is a database containing an electronic version of the centers’ output. Using the simple EONS tools the user can view the individual stored documents that include summary and statistical information needed for into the balancing process. ) PCI is divided into a number of components and is run on the UNISYS . There is a batch component that runs before the application program. is the user interface component, and there is the component that kicks in matically whenever ICI/ATIS gets a message. (

) The PCI batch component generates and executes PRT,F statements that search the system catalog for speciﬁc ﬁles. This updates the PCI information about ﬁles. It tracks the information of a newly created ﬁle and (

deleted ﬁles. PCI then scans its databases looking for eligible unprocessed ﬁles. If it ﬁnds such ﬁles, PCI stages the ﬁle into the target application and issues messages to the console telling AMS how to answer the upcoming prompts. (

) The PCI user interface program is a series of screens that allow people to interact with the PCI databases. From the main menu, a person can: • display information about runs and ﬁles; • back out runs; • preview inputs; • look at past AMS parameter ﬁles; • place on hold, ﬁles that haven’t been processed; • release ﬁles that are on hold. (
) PCI routes predetermined ﬁles into awaiting inventory to ensure they are veriﬁed before they are committed to processing. (

) When a ﬁle is channel extended to the ATL, a message routes from the machine to the UNISYS ICI/ATIS interface. There the ﬁle is catalogued on UNISYS system. Then PCI counts the number of records on the ﬁle and the information to the PCI databases. (

) To add information about new ﬁles to PCI use PCI batch preview and F The catalogue search in PCI batch will post new ﬁles. The PCI preview ﬁnds new ﬁles as well as the PCI display waiting inventory option. Channel extended ﬁles are captured and placed in the PCI databases via ICI/ATIS control. Files are also found via ﬁle tracking report. Note: It is important to remember if you are using PCI to see if a ﬁle has been catalogued. (A ﬁle may have been catalogued but not be in the PCI unless a preview or a waiting inventory option is invoked.) ) From the ’File’ screen it is possible to place a hold on a ﬁle. A held ﬁle is considered an eligible input and will not be staged into a run. A held ﬁle Inputs Under be released, and when released it becomes an eligible input. (

) Once a ﬁle has been staged into a run, it won’t be staged into that run For this reason it is sometimes necessary to use the Back Out a Run option. If a run must be restaged, or the inputs into it changed, back run out. When backing out a run, the user will provide the run name and run sequence number. The inputs that were staged into the run will then be marked as not having been staged into that run and will be considered for the next PCI Run. (
) Use the Display “Preview” of Run option to verify what PCI would do if PCI batch jobs ran at that moment. The ﬁles that PCI would stage are listed under the run selected for preview. (

) The following examples are intended to help clarify how PCI works from a user’s perspective. Remember that the preview option ﬁnds inputs and what PCI would do if it ran, but the preview does not schedule the ﬁles. (

) Example One of implementing PCI for the ﬁrst time to support a run: a. Do a preview and see inputs staged that have already been b. Place holds on the ﬁles that need to be skipped. c. Do a preview and see only the correct inputs staged. d. When PCI runs, the correct inputs get staged. (
) Example Two of implementing PCI for the ﬁrst time to support a run.

The following examples are intended to help clarify how PCI works from a user’s perspective. Remember that the preview option ﬁnds inputs and sees what PCI would do if it ran, but the preview does not schedule the ﬁles.
Two of implementing PCI for the ﬁrst time to support a run.

Information Technology (IT) a. Do a preview and see inputs staged that have already been b. Place holds on the ﬁles that are to be input. c. Run the PCI job. The undesired inputs are now staged. d. Release the holds on the ﬁles that were held in step b. e. Do a preview and see only the correct inputs staged. f. When PCI runs, the correct ﬁles get staged. (

) Example Three of a rerun of an application because a ﬁle was left out. a. Make sure the missing input is cataloged. b. Prepare the application for a rerun. c. Use the PCI back out option to make the original inputs eligible. d. Do a preview to ensure the correct ﬁles are picked up. e. When PCI runs, the correct ﬁles get staged. (

) Example Four of a rerun of an application because an incorrect ﬁle was processed. a. Prepare the application for a rerun. b. Use the PCI back out option to make the original inputs eligible for the next running. c. Place a hold on the ﬁle that is to be held out. d. Do a preview to ensure the correct ﬁles are picked up. e. When PCI runs, the correct ﬁles get staged. (
) PCI will not stage a ﬁle that has been deleted. PCI will still track it for audit purposes. (

) PCI will not stage a tape ﬁle that does not have a volume serial number. a ﬁle will still appear in the inventories for audit trail purposes. Adding the volume to the catalog will not change things. It still won’t be input. Deleting such a ﬁle and then re-cataloging it with the volume serial number will work. (
) PCI uses the catalog name and time stamp information as the key in the ﬁle database. (

) Enterprise Computing Centers (ECCs) use Opcon/xps, a software package from SMA, to perform many functions being done by REX in the IRSCs on UNISYS system. Opcon/xps will automate job scheduling and take over the portion of REX involved starting and linking runs, however, it will not build runstreams. MREX, a modiﬁed version of REX, will perform that function. MREX will run as a batch job and will build runstreams into the ﬁle *MREX- PRODYYYY. SMA provides a program, SAMREX, to interface with their Schedule File. This program extracts the runids of the runstreams to be and then passes them to MREX.

SAMREX runs at the beginning of each schedule day, and as Processing needed, when jobs are added to the Daily Schedule. It should be set to run through Opcon and to use the ECL provided by SMA SAMREXECL). SAMREX extracts, from the Daily Schedule ﬁle, the RUNIDs for all jobs whose ECL is found in the ﬁle *MREXPROD and places them in a ﬁle scab*SAMREX-FILE in a format similar to the original REX prompt that is: (

Field

in the REX prompt is a SETC value. MREX ignores this value. xps uses the SETC or Condition Word value from the STR screen when starts the job. If a SETC value is needed for a run, it should be entered STR screen for the job in either the master or daily schedule. SAMREX will automatically start the correct MREX runs. The MREX runs be set up in the Opcon/xps with a dependency on SAMREX. The userid should be PROD, the account should be PROD (or ALN+PROD in the environment), and the project should be “scab”. MREX is a batch program and does not have any outstanding console messages. MREX reads the SAMREX-FILE that contains a list of one or RUNIDs. MREX: • locates the correct ECL based on the search sequence REX uses; • rebuilds the ECL using the same resources as REX; • places the updated ECL in a ﬁle *MREXPRODYYYY. • places all add elements in the *runid-ADD ﬁle. Each production run to be built by MREX must be deﬁned in the with an ECL location of *MREXPRODYYYY. MREX attempts to locate the main runstream by searching the following sequence: • scab*TECL, • scab*RUNECL, • SOFT*LIB, • STAR*LIB, • IRSTIP*SETUP, • DMS*DBRUNS, • DMS*DMURUNS, • DMS*DMRMT, • CPE*CPE, • SYS$*RUN$.
